 Document(page_content='77 \n Score:  \n5. \nCheck (10  Points)  \nBet $500 (0  Points)  \nBet $750 (3  Points)  \nBet $1,000 (1  Point)  \nBet $1,250 (4  Points)  \n \nThis is possibly the worst card in the deck for your top two -pair because you now \nlose to all flushes, A -A, and K -K. Perhaps more importantly, it is nearly impossible \nfor you to bet for value because there should now be very few bluffs in your \nrange, meaning your opponent should rarely make a hero -call. \nChecking and taking your free showdown is easily the best option. You still beat a \nfew hands like A -Q, J-J, and A -K. It is very difficult for you to be called by a worse \nhand if you make a “normal”  bet, so if you are going to bet, you should choose a \nsmall sizing of $750. The option I actually like better is to turn your full house \nblockers into a bluff by betting $1,250. You would certainly keep betting with your \nfull houses and flushes, so you sho uld at least consider turning your hand into a \nbluff to make your opponent fold his A -A and K -K. However, you should only \nattempt this bluff against players who are capable of making a big fold.  \nYou decided to check and your opponent wins the pot with K -K.  \n \nYou end up a small loser on the session.', metadata={'source': 'players/jonathan_little/little_pdfs/workbook.pdf', 'page': 76}),

 Document(page_content='79 \n Set Up  \nThe following five hands took place during the last year in live poker tournaments. \nIn 2016, I made a conscious decision to play more live poker. This was difficult for \nme because I teach so many students on a regular basis. However, in the seven \nevents I played, I was able to make a WPT final table, another small final table, \nand finished deep in the money in the WSOP Main Event and another WPT main \nevent.  \nWhat really he lped me be more consistent was an emphasis on improving my \ntechnical skills. I’ve accepted that my live reading skills are subpar, so what \nfollows is an exploration into how you can put your live opponents on ranges \nmore effectively.  \nFor simplicity’s sake,  all blind levels have been adjusted to 500/1,000 with a 100 \nante. These standardized blinds will allow you to more easily digest the material.', metadata={'source': 'players/jonathan_little/little_pdfs/workbook.pdf', 'page': 78}),
 Document(page_content='80 \n Taking Advantage of Aggressive Players  \nThis first hand took place in Prague. The action was fast and furious, with many \nyoung European pros making me fold with their consistent aggression.  \nMost people don’t realize it, but  selectively choosing the hands with which  you \nenter pots will help you overcome these over tly aggressive fields.  Let’s pick a spot \non the prec ipice to start.  \nWith Jd -Td on the button and 70 big blinds, everyone folds to the lojack. The \noverly aggressive lojack , in his early 20’s , raises to 2,500, for 2.5 big blinds.  The \nhijack folds.  The c utoff, another 20 -something 3 -bets using a small sizing to 6,000.  \n \nShould you:  \n1. \nFold  \nCall  \nReraise to 14,500  \nReraise to 18,000', metadata={'source': 'players/jonathan_little/little_pdfs/workbook.pdf', 'page': 79}),
 Document(page_content='81 \n Score:  \n1. \nFold (5 Points)  \nCall (0 Points)  \nReraise to 14,500 (10 Points)  \nReraise to 18,000 (8 Points)  \n \nI really like to use, what I call a “4 -bet semi -bluff” here.  \nIf you have been quiet throughout the day, your opponents will logically assume \nthat you are a tight player. They are playing their little war games, and assume \nany other bluffing -style player would have joined them by now.  \nIf you look at your hand, look a t your chips quickly, and then make a small 4 -bet, \nyou will look exactly like a rock with Aces.  \nThe initial raiser will fold because he doesn’t have much invested and he likely \ndoesn’t have much of a hand.  \nThe 3 -bettor will usually flat call you, try to c rack your “Aces”, and then fold when \nhe doesn’t.  \nWhile this may not seem like much, you will pick up almost 10 big blinds if \neveryone folds. That’s close to your exact expectation with a pair of Aces! It’s like \ndealing yourself the best hand in Hold’em, i f you can pick good times to run this \nsemi -bluff.  \nSimply folding is never out of the question, however. In fact, that’s what I do 95% \nof the time when facing a raise and a reraise.  \nI never cold call the 3 -bet because it costs too many chips to fold when o ne of \nthese aggressive players bets the flop and I (likely) miss.  \nA larger 4 -bet is fine, but you have a decent hand if you get called, so I’d save the \nlarger cold 4 -bet for a real junky hand, like A -2o.', metadata={'source': 'players/jonathan_little/little_pdfs/workbook.pdf', 'page': 80}),

 Document(page_content='83 \n Score:  \n2. \nCheck (0 Points)  \nBet 11,500 (10 Points)  \nBet 15,500 (7 Points)  \nBet 20,000 (5 Points)  \n \nYou should continuation bet 11,500 because that looks exactly like a big pair that \nis trying to milk value out of your opponent. It’s very unlikely he will continue with \nany hand that has not solidly hit the board. For this reason, a bigger bet probably \nwon’t increase your fold equity much more than a small bet. The hands that hit \nare going to defend, and the hands that missed are going to fold.  \nIf you are worried about a check -raise bluff from  your opponent, rest assured \nmost people will not do that.  Document(page_content='91 \n Score:  \n4. \nCheck (0 Points)  \nBet 20,000 (0 Points)  \nGo all -in (10 Points)  \n \nGoing all -in is your only viable option.  \nThis player has identified himself as a “poker player”. Even if you gave \nhim every plausible flush draw, he only has flushes 20% of the time. That’s \nanother way of saying he missed that river 80% of the time. And it’s far more \nlikely that number is 85% or 90% given the possibility of hi m check -raising \npremium flush draws at some other juncture.  \nFinally, in live tournaments, people have to turn their hand face -up when they call \nan all -in. If he folds, he still has a \nvery comfortable stack.  \nThis is why I don’t like it when people split the difference with a smaller bet.  Document(page_content='95 \n Score:  \n2. \nCheck (10 Points)  \nBet 3,000 (8 Points)  \n \nI actually do n ot find leading out on this flop to be a bad play.  Document(page_content='99 \n Score:  \n4. \nCheck (10 Points)  \nBet 6,000 (8 Points)  \n \nThere is a great deal of merit in leading the turn here.  \nOn the flop, your opponent was likely to bet with his entire range because you \nonly completed from the big blind and then checked to him.  Document(page_content='105 \n Score:  \n7. \nFold (10 Points)  \nCall (0 Points)  \n \nI am a huge fan of folding in this spot.  \nIf there is one thing I have been working at this last year, it’s been not to give \naway a river bet.  \nAt face value, this seems like a basic call. You have tons of chips, there are \nmultiple missed draws possible, you have top pair. Why are you folding?  \nWell, pocket Aces on avera ge makes you about 10 -12 big blinds per deal. Have \nyou ever heard a guy say, “Oh, I could win poker tournaments too if I got dealt \nAces four times like that one kid!”  \nWell, every time you bet 10 big blinds on the river and get called by a worse hand, \nyou j ust dealt yourself Aces. Every time you call a 10 big blind bet on the river and \nare wrong, you just got dealt Aces while you were in the restroom.  \nIt’s actually worse than that, but to keep things simple, it is a good visualization \ntechnique to realize ho w important river bets are to both win and save.  \nThink about it: What is he betting that you beat?  \nMissed draws. Think of all the missed draws. List them out. K -Q of hearts? How \nmany combinations are there of that hand?  \nOne. The answer is one.  \nNow how many  A-K combinations are there? There are eight. Two suited \ncombinations and six unsuited ones.  \nK-Qs, K -Js, K -10s, Q -Js, Q -10s, Q -9s, J-10s, 10 -9s: All those missed flush draws \naccount for exactly one type of top pair. You haven’t even gotten into the A -Q and  \nA-J combinations. Also , most of his weaker Aces that he would continue betting \nhave made two -pair.', metadata={'source': 'players/jonathan_little/little_pdfs/workbook.pdf', 'page': 104}),
 Document(page_content='106 \n If you don’t know what to do on the river, just fold. People are awful at bluffing, \nand they call too often.  Document(page_content='108 \n Score:  \n1. \nFold (8 Points)  \nCall (6 Points)  \nRaise to 3,000 ( 3 Points)  \nRaise to 5,000 (10 Points)  \n \nI raised to 5,000.  Document(page_content='109 \n The Un changing Board  \nThis hand took place in Las Vegas in a small stakes tournament at Planet \nHollywood.  Document(page_content='110 \n Score:  \n1. \nCheck (0 Points)  \nBet 6,000 (10 Points)  \nBet 12,000 (5 Points)  \n \nI used to never double barrel in this situation, but I’ve gradually added it to my \nrepertoire.  \nThe reas on I have done this is because deep -stacked regulars will not fold Ace -\nhigh on hit -or-miss boards (like this one) anymore. [Document(page_content='Strategies for Beating Small Stakes Poker Tournaments\nBy Jonathan Little\nEdited by Ken Adams', metadata={'source': 'players/jonathan_little/little_pdfs/Strategies.pdf', 'page': 1}),
 Document(page_content='Contents\nFree Bonus Video & PDF\nIntroduction\nFocus on your opponents\nThe three player types who play small stakes tournaments\nThose who play too many hands\nThose who play too many hands too passively\nThose who play too many hands too aggressively\nThose who play too few hands\nThose who play too few hands too passively\nThose who play too few hands too aggressively\nThose who play roughly the correct amount of hands in an intelligent manner\nPay attention!\nSpecific tendencies you will encounter in small stakes tournaments\nConclusion\nResources', metadata={'source': 'players/jonathan_little/little_pdfs/Strategies.pdf', 'page': 2}),
 Document(page_content='Free\tBonus\tVideo\t&\tPDF\n \nOne of the most impactful things you can do to immediately improve your tournament\nstrategy is to learn how to increase your levels of aggression.  However, it must be\ndone intelligently for it to be effective.  The secret is to learn when to play aggressively\nand when to get out of the way.\nTo get a free 11-minute video and 24-page PDF from me with tips on how to increase\nyour levels of aggression, visit:\nFloatTheTurn.com/increasingaggression', metadata={'source': 'players/jonathan_little/little_pdfs/Strategies.pdf', 'page': 3}),
 Document(page_content='Introduction\n \nThere has been a lot written recently, particularly in eBook format, regarding how to\nbeat small stakes poker tournaments. Most books suggest that you either play an\noverly tight strategy, hoping to trap your opponents who never fold, or an overly loose\nstrategy, hoping to steal lots of pots from your opponents who fold too often. In\nreality, you should play a strategy that maximally exploits your specific opponents.\nI hate to be the bearer of bad news, but there is no silver bullet, as many of these\neBooks suggest. Guides that aim to teach you a default set of hands to play from each\nposition are certain to fail you in the long run because each and every time you sit at a\npoker table, you play against a different set of opponents. For example, if you elect to\nplay an overly tight style, and you employ that strategy against players who will never\npay you off when you make a strong hand, you will blind out, guaranteeing failure. If\nyou instead play overly loose, against opponents who play in a manner that traps you,\nyou will spew off your stack. You should not accept the idea that sometimes your\nstrategy will simply fail when you get unlucky to be against the wrong type of\nopponents.\nIt is also worth mentioning that you should raise with a drastically different range\nbased on your stack size. Hands such as 4-4 and 9\n-7\n are excellent when you have a', metadata={'source': 'players/jonathan_little/little_pdfs/Strategies.pdf', 'page': 4}),
 Document(page_content='deep stack because of their potential to win a large number of chips if you flop well.\nHowever, if you have a 30 big blind stack, they become quite poor, especially from\nearly position, because if you get lucky to flop well, you cannot win enough to justify\nlosing the amount you lose when you don’t connect with the flop or when you get\nreraised and have to fold before the flop.\nOne of the best things you can do to improve your tournament skills is to learn how to\nincrease your levels aggression. That being said, aggression must be implemented\nintelligently to be effective.  The key to using aggression effectively is knowing when to\napply it and when to get out of the way.\nTo get a free 11-minute video and 24-page PDF from me with tips on how to increase\nyour levels of aggression, visit:\nFloatTheTurn.com/increasingaggression\n \nThe secret to success in poker is to tailor your playing style to your specific opponents.\nPlaying according to a simple hand chart doesn’t work because your opponents are not\nall playing the same way. Also, you will find that most of these books lay out an overly\nsimplistic strategy for playing after the flop. Again, this will fail miserably because it\ndoesn’t account for opponents’ tendencies.', metadata={'source': 'players/jonathan_little/little_pdfs/Strategies.pdf', 'page': 5}),
 Document(page_content='As a simple example, suppose you raise with A\n-J\n to 2.5 big blinds out of your 75 big\nblind stack from middle position and only the player in the big blind calls. The flop\ncomes J\n-7\n-3\n. Your opponent checks.\nAgainst almost all opponents, you should make a continuation bet of around 3 big\nblinds, which is roughly 50% of the size of the pot. Let’s assume you make that bet and\nyour opponent calls.\nThe turn is the (J\n-7\n-3\n)-Q\n.  Your opponent checks. At this point, your play should\nvary widely based on your opponent’s tendencies. Against tight players who will fold\nalmost all hands worse than yours if you bet, you should check, forcing them to stay in\nthe pot with lots of hands that you crush. Against loose players who never fold any\nmade hand or draw to a turn bet, you should bet to get value from worse made hands\nand to protect your hand from various river cards that could give your opponent the\nhand. Let’s assume you are against a loose player and you decide to bet 50% of the pot\nagain. Your opponent calls.\nThe river is the (J\n-7\n-3\n-Q\n)-9\n. Your opponent checks. Your play now depends on\nhow prone your opponent is to call on the river with his marginal hands. If he will call\na river bet with an overly wide range of marginal made hands, such as J-8 and A-7, you\nshould make a thin value bet. It is important to bet an amount that is likely to get\ncalled by these junky made hands. In this situation, a bet of around 25% of the size of\nthe pot should get called a large portion of the time. If your opponent will usually fold\nall hands worse than yours besides perhaps J-T and J-8, you should probably check', metadata={'source': 'players/jonathan_little/little_pdfs/Strategies.pdf', 'page': 6}),
 Document(page_content='behind because if you get called, it is too likely that you no longer have the best hand.\nThis simple example shows how mindlessly thinking “I have top pair, so I should bet”\ndoes not work. If you were to bet the turn and river in this scenario against a tight\nopponent, you are almost certainly burning money because he will only call you with a\nbetter hand. If you fail to make a thin value bet against a calling station on the river,\nyou are leaving money on the table. If you fail to alter your play based on your\nopponent’s tendencies, you will not win the maximum your winning hands and you\nwill lose more than you should with your losing hands. My goal is to teach you to crush\nyour opponents, not merely win a small amount from them by playing robotically.\nAs with all of my poker training content, my goal is to teach you to think for yourself,\nso you will be able to select the best possible play in all situations you encounter for\nthe rest of your poker career.
