 Document(page_content='Focus\ton\tyour\topponents\n \nIn order to win large amounts, you must focus on your opponents. You have to keep\nyour eyes and ears open, actively observing their tendencies. If you only pay attention\nto your own two cards, your position and your chip stack, you are certain to fail in the\nlong run. Fortunately for you, in the small stakes games, most of your opponents will\nbe oblivious to what you are doing, giving you free reign to do whatever you want.\nYou must make a point to diligently pay attention the action during each and every\nhand that takes place at the table. Paying attention only when you are involved in a\npot will not give you enough reliable information to get well out of line, which is\nmandatory if you are to maximize your equity. You have to be mindful while playing\npoker. If you are mindlessly grinding, you are not playing optimally.\nI strongly suggest that you either take mental notes about everything you see your\nopponents doing, assuming your memory is good, or write notes in a notepad if your\nmemory is bad. Because I recognize and accept that my memory is bad, I write down\nevery hand I play as well as a decent amount of the hands I witness at the poker table.\nWhile I occasionally get teased for actually taking the game seriously, I exploit my \nopponents better than almost anyone.  That seems like a fine tradeoff to me!', metadata={'source': 'players/jonathan_little/little_pdfs/Strategies.pdf', 'page': 10}),
 Document(page_content='When taking notes on your opponents, it is especially important to record what each\nspecific player does incorrectly. For example, if you see someone on separate occasions\nmaking very small and very large continuation bets on the flop, you should assume\nthat those bet sizes mean something. If you pay attention long enough, you will be\nable to see a few showdowns and figure out if a particular bet size correlates with a\nhand of a specific strength.\nOnce you figure out what your specific opponent is doing incorrectly, you can take\nsteps to exploit his weakness, which is how you will produce a large profit in the long\nrun.\nFor example, if you know your opponent continuation bets small on the flop with\nstrong hands and large with weak hands, you should fold all of your non-premium\nmade hands to small continuation bets. When facing a large continuation bet, you\nshould raise with your weak hands, forcing your opponent to fold, earning you the pot.\nWith your strong hands, you should call because if you raise, your opponent will fold,\nmaking it impossible to extract additional value on the turn and river.\nBefore moving forward, there is a concept you must grasp if you want to win at any\nform of poker. If you do not understand this concept, you are certain to fail once you\nprogress beyond the small stakes. Pay attention, this is important!\nYou must make a point to always think in terms of ranges, meaning you must accept\nthat your opponents will play various hands in a similar manner. For example, if a', metadata={'source': 'players/jonathan_little/little_pdfs/Strategies.pdf', 'page': 11}),
 Document(page_content='super-tight player raises from first position, you should not assume he has a specific\nhand, such as A-K. You should assume he has a range of hands, such as A-A, K-K, Q-Q, J-\nJ and A-K. You can then narrow that range as the hand progresses based on your\nopponent’s actions. Obviously looser players will have much wider ranges on all\nbetting rounds, making them more difficult to play against. There will be more\ndiscussion about ranges throughout this book simply because you cannot analyze a\npoker hand without assigning your opponent a range.\nWhen you have your opponent’s range crushed, such as when you have a straight and\nyou think the best hand your opponent can realistically have is one pair, you do NOT\nwant him to fold. You win at poker by making your opponent fold when you are beat\nand by getting value when you are decently far ahead.\nSuppose you raise to 250 out of your 5,000 stack at 50/100 with A\n-T\n from middle\nposition and only the big blind calls.\nThe flop comes A\n-7\n-2\n. The pot is 550. Your opponent, who you know nothing\nabout, decides to bet into you for 400.\nThis is a scenario where if you raise, your opponent will probably only call with a flush\ndraw or a strong made hand, unless he is a calling station who cannot fold any sort of\nmarginal holding. We will assume that is not the case. This means that if you raise and\nget called, you are either against a draw that has roughly 40% equity (meaning you are\nnot too far ahead) or against what is likely a better made hand (meaning you are way', metadata={'source': 'players/jonathan_little/little_pdfs/Strategies.pdf', 'page': 12}),
 Document(page_content='behind). Even though you “probably” have the best hand with your top pair, when you\nraise your opponent’s flop bet and he continues in the pot, you are usually in either\nmarginal or bad shape. Of course, if your opponent decides to reraise, you are in even\nworse shape.\nA much better play is to call, forcing your opponent to stay in the pot with a wide\nrange of hands that you crush, including A\n-5\n and 8\n-7\n. While you will occasionally\nget outdrawn, you will also extract huge amounts of value by giving your opponent a\nchance to make mistakes on the turn and river. Notice that your opponent may think\nhis A\n-5\n is the best hand and continue betting on the turn and river for value\nbecause he may assume you would always raise with a better hand on the flop. He\ncould also have total air, such as K\n-5\n, and decide to continue bluffing because he\nknows you can’t have the nut flush draw or simply because he feels like running a\nbluff. By raising the flop and forcing your opponent to fold his hands that are drawing\nthin, you force him to play perfectly. You make money by exploiting your opponent’s\nerrors, not by inducing him to play well.', metadata={'source': 'players/jonathan_little/little_pdfs/Strategies.pdf', 'page': 13}),
 Document(page_content='The\tthree\tplayer\ttypes\twho\tplay\tsmall\nstakes\ttournaments\n \nThere are primarily three types of players who play small stakes tournaments. There\nare those who play too many hands, those who play too few hands and those who\nplay roughly the correct amount of hands in an intelligent manner. While many of\nthese players have similar traits, they all have distinguishing characteristics that allow\nyou to syphon away their money, assuming you are paying attention and adjusting\nintelligently.', metadata={'source': 'players/jonathan_little/little_pdfs/Strategies.pdf', 'page': 14}),
 Document(page_content='Those\twho\tplay\ttoo\tmany\thands\n \nWhile players who play too many hands come in numerous varieties, you can generally\nbreak this category of players down into those who play too many hands too passively\nand those who play too many hands too aggressively. Each player type must be looked\nat separately because you exploit them in drastically different ways.', metadata={'source': 'players/jonathan_little/little_pdfs/Strategies.pdf', 'page': 15}),
 Document(page_content='Those\twho\tplay\ttoo\tmany\thands\ttoo\npassively\n \nThe main type of player you will encounter in small stakes poker tournaments are\nthose who play too many hands too passively. These players frequently limp in and\ncall raises with a wide range of marginal hands, hoping to connect well with the flop.\nIt is important to realize that these players usually have marginal hands when they act\nin a passive manner because they almost always raise and reraise with their premium\nhands.\nJust because someone is active does not mean they are aggressive. It is quite easy to\nbe involved in many pots while still only investing significant money with premium\nhands. That is exactly what these players do. They try to make a premium post-flop\nhand cheaply before investing a lot of money. Of course, the type of hand that each\nspecific player perceives as strong varies quite a bit. Some will only want to put a lot of\nmoney in the pot with the nuts and others will blast their stack in with any junky top\npair. As stated earlier, you must pay attention to your opponents so you can develop a\nplan for how you should exploit them. It is impossible to develop a sound plan if you\nhave no clue what your opponents are doing.', metadata={'source': 'players/jonathan_little/little_pdfs/Strategies.pdf', 'page': 16}),
 Document(page_content='You beat this type of player by assuming they play straightforwardly. Of course, they\nwill bluff you from time to time, but you will usually make the right decision if you\nassume they are playing in a face-up manner.\nWhen this type of player calls your bets, you should tend to assume they have\nmarginal made hands. This should lead you to value bet relentlessly, especially with\nhands that have their calling range crushed. Whenever you have a decent top pair or\nbetter, you should almost always continue value betting. Always be sure to size your\nbets such that your opponent can realistically call with worse made hands.\nWhen this type of player decides to apply pressure, you should tend to get out of the\nway unless you have a premium holding that is in good shape against their\nbetting/raising range. If you know your opponent is betting and raising with mostly nut\nand near-nut hands, it is tough to be ahead of that range! Do not fall into the habit of\npaying these players off with strong, but crushed holdings, such as top pair.\nFor example, suppose you raise to 3 big blinds with K\n-Q\n out of your 100 big blind\nstack and a loose, passive player calls on the button. The flop comes K\n-T\n-7\n. You\nshould usually make a continuation bet of around 4 big blinds. If your opponent calls,\nyou should usually bet again on most turns. Suppose the turn is the (K\n-T\n-7\n)-6\n.\nYou should bet around 7 big blinds. If your opponent calls, you can assume he has a\nworse K, a T or a draw. If he raises, you can confidently fold, assuming he has you beat\nwith some sort of two pair or set that he decided to slow play on the flop. This turn\nbet allows you to extract value when you are ahead while also getting relatively', metadata={'source': 'players/jonathan_little/little_pdfs/Strategies.pdf', 'page': 17}),
 Document(page_content='accurate information that will let you know when you are crushed.\nAssuming the river is a reasonably safe card (any card besides an A, J or 9) you should\nmake a fairly small value bet of around 10 big blinds, or 33% of the size of the pot. You\nare making this bet with the assumption that your opponent will fold all of his missed\ndraws, call with all of his one pair hands and either call or raise with hands that are\nbetter than yours. While the T may appear to be a scary river card because it improves\nmiddle pair into trips, you should not automatically assume that your opponent has\nexactly the one hand that beats yours. Of course, if your opponent raises your river\nvalue bet, unless you have some sort of read that lets you know with a high degree of\ncertainty that he is bluffing, you should fold.\nIt is important to realize that when you value bet on some of these rivers, such as a T,\n9, 8, 7, 6 or 5, you could have the worst hand. However, you will find that your\nopponent will call your small bet often enough with a losing hand to justify making the\nvalue bet. When value betting, your bet needs to get called by a worse hand at least\n50% of the time to make the bet profitable. In this scenario, it almost certainly will\nsucceed at least 50% of the time. That being said, if you know your opponent only calls\nriver bets with premium hands, you should strongly consider checking with the\nintention of calling if your opponent bets on these marginal rivers.\nIf the river is a bad card (an A, J or 9), you should usually check and see what your\nopponent does. If he bets, you should vary your play between calling and folding,\ndepending on your opponent’s specific tendencies, although folding is usually the', metadata={'source': 'players/jonathan_little/little_pdfs/Strategies.pdf', 'page': 18}),
 Document(page_content='intelligent play. Whenever the river is great for your opponent’s range and bad for\nyour hand, if your passive opponent bets, you should usually assume he improved to a\nhand that crushes yours.\nNotice that if you bet significantly larger, perhaps around 75% of the size of the pot,\nwhich is what most non-thinking players do, your opponent will fold most of his one\npair hands, meaning he will usually only call when you are beat. By making a large bet,\nyou force your opponent to play well, which is a disaster for you. Remember, you don’t\nwant to make it easy for your opponent to play well.\nYou will often find that some of these players will call on the flop and the turn with a\nwide range, hoping to either “find out where they are at by the river” or improve their\njunky holdings, such as A high or bottom pair, into a strong hand. Against these\nplayers, you should be very prone to make river bluffs, especially if you know that your\nopponent will raise on an earlier betting round with his premium holdings, meaning\nwhen he calls your flop and turn bet, he usually has a marginal made hand that he will\nfold to a sizable river bet.\nAgainst these players, you should usually make your river bets a bit larger than in the\nprevious example because you are trying to make your opponent fold most of his\nmarginal hands. The last thing you want is to bet small on the river with a bluff and\nhave your opponent call with bottom pair.\nFor example, suppose you raise to 2.5 big blinds out of your 75 big blind stack with Q\n-', metadata={'source': 'players/jonathan_little/little_pdfs/Strategies.pdf', 'page': 19}),
 Document(page_content='J\n.  A player who you know likes to stick around until the river with a wide range calls \non the button. The flop comes K\n-9\n-3\n. You bet 3.5 big blinds and your opponent\ncalls. The turn is the (K\n-9\n-3\n)-5\n. You bet 5 big blinds and your opponent calls. The\nriver is the (K\n-9\n-3\n-5\n)-7\n. Should you bet or check? If you decide to bet, how much\nshould you bet?\nSeeing how you lose to almost all hands and your opponent could realistically fold a 9,\n3, A or marginal pocket pair if you bet, you should make a somewhat sizable bet of\naround 15 big blinds, or 65% of the size of the pot. This will force your opponent to\nput in a significant amount of his stack to make a hero call that will only win if you are\nbluffing. Of course, if you are known to be a habitual bluffer, you should be more\nprone to give up when you miss. On the other hand, if you are known to be a tight\nplayer, you should certainly bluff. Always be sure to factor in the way your opponent\nperceives you before making any bet.\nInterestingly, if you improve to a straight or flush on the river, you should bet for\nvalue. Since you expect your opponent to fold to a large bet, you should make a\nsmaller bet of around 40% of the size of the pot. If you improve to middle pair, you\nshould also make a 40% pot bet for value because you expect most of your opponent’s\nrange to be worse than your middle pair.\nThis is an example of playing a blatantly exploitable strategy, which means that if your\nopponent knows what you are doing, he can crush you. If he knows that you are\nbluffing when you bet 65% pot, he can simply call with his entire range of made hands', metadata={'source': 'players/jonathan_little/little_pdfs/Strategies.pdf', 'page': 20}),
 Document(page_content='and raise with all of his trash. When you bet 40% pot, he can fold all of his marginal\nmade hands. Clearly, if your opponent knows what you are doing, you have a major\nproblem.\nHowever, you will rarely stumble into this exact situation too often. You will find that\nyou rarely make it to the river and when you do, your opponents will not be paying\ntoo much attention to your exact bet sizes. Most small stakes players don’t pay\nattention to what is going on at the table when they aren’t involved in the pot, which\nis one of the main reasons why most of them never progress beyond the small stakes\ngames.\nIf you play with the same group of strong players on a regular basis, you should tend\nto make bets that are unexploitable, or at least much more difficult to exploit. This\nmeans that you should make bets of the same size with all of your hands, whether\nthey are strong or weak. In the previous situation, you should tend to make the 65%\npot bet because most of the time, you will want this type of player to fold on the river.\nIn general, you want to figure out the result you want most of the time and tailor your\nbet size to achieve that result.\nSome players of this type will display obvious bet sizing tells, meaning they make a\nspecific bet size with their strong hands and a vastly different bet size with their weak\nhands. For example, they may bet 1/3 pot with their middle and bottom pair hands\nand 2/3 pot with their top pair or better hands. Others will raise or check-raise with\ntop pair or better while calling with their worse made hands. Whatever they do, try to', metadata={'source': 'players/jonathan_little/little_pdfs/Strategies.pdf', 'page': 21}),
 Document(page_content='figure out what their bet sizes mean and act accordingly until you have a reason to\nbelieve that they have altered their betting patterns, which will likely never happen.\nOnce you figure out what your opponents are doing incorrectly, you can adjust your\nstrategy to exploit them.', metadata={'source': 'players/jonathan_little/little_pdfs/Strategies.pdf', 'page': 22}),
 Document(page_content='Those\twho\tplay\ttoo\tmany\thands\ttoo\naggressively\n \nThis type of player is similar to the previous type of player in that they play a wide\nrange of hands and see a lot of flops. However, they tend to do so in an aggressive\nmanner, which makes them much more difficult to play against than their passive\ncounterparts. Instead of being able to assume these players play in an almost blatantly\nface-up manner, you have to assume they are bluffing at least some percentage of the\ntime. This makes it much more difficult to accurately assess their ranges.\nThese players act in an aggressive manner because they have learned that most of\ntheir opponents play in a straightforward manner. They also know that most of their\nopponents will not want to call multiple bets without a premium holding. This leads\nthem to bet whenever they sense weakness, which is primarily when their opponents\ncheck. Against the average player in small stakes tournaments, this is an excellent\nstrategy to apply. These players are usually winners in the small stakes games although\nthey will get crushed once they move up and face players who know how to combat\nthem.\nYou can beat this type of player in a few ways. The primary way to beat them is to', metadata={'source': 'players/jonathan_little/little_pdfs/Strategies.pdf', 'page': 23}),
 Document(page_content='induce them to try to bluff you. Of course, if you induce your opponent to try to bluff\nyou, you should not fold whatever you have unless the board runs out as poorly for\nyou as possible, which shouldn’t happen too often if you choose your spots well.\nThe most obvious way to induce an opponent to bluff into you is to check as if you\nhave a weak hand and are going to concede the pot. For example, suppose you raise to\n2.5 big blinds out of your 50 big blind stack with A\n-T\n from middle position and an\naggressive players who play too many hands calls on the button.\nThe flop comes A\n-7\n-4\n. You make a standard continuation bet of 3.5 big blinds and\nyour opponent calls. On most turns, you should strongly consider checking instead of\nbetting for value. While this is often referred to as “controlling the pot”, you are\nactually inducing a bluff against this type of player because you should expect him to\nfold most of his marginal hands if you bet. However, he will usually bet if you check. By\nchecking, you get him to put much more money in the pot compared to when you\ncheck, which is exactly what you want to happen when you probably have the best\nhand.\nThe turn is the (A\n-7\n-4\n)-9\n. You check and your opponent bets 8 big blinds into the\n13 big blind pot. This is a scenario where lots of amateur players elect to check-raise,\ntrying to force their opponent to fold all of their draws. While your opponent will\nprobably fold his draws, he will also fold all of the hands that you crush, such as A-2, 8-\n7, 4-3 and K-J. Instead of check-raising, you should check-call with the intention of\ncheck-calling all rivers.', metadata={'source': 'players/jonathan_little/little_pdfs/Strategies.pdf', 'page': 24}),
 Document(page_content='When you call your opponent’s turn bet, don’t look overly happy or act in a fast\nmanner as if calling is the only option that makes sense. That could tip your opponent\noff to the fact that you have a strong holding. Instead, act as if you have a tough\ndecision with a hand such as J-J or 8-7. Remember, you want your opponent to bet\nagain on the river.\nWhile you will get outdrawn roughly 15% of the time when you play your hand in this\nmanner, you will find that most of your aggressive opponents cannot resist the\nopportunity to try to push you off your “obviously” weak hand. When you show up\nwith top pair on the river, most of them will be shocked, thinking that the only way to\nplay top pair is to bet it for value and protection on all three streets. By checking, you\nwill crush these opponents.\nNotice that in this example, there are not too many bad turn and river cards for you.\nWhile an 8 or 3 would complete the most likely straight draw, the other cards are fairly\nsafe. If instead of A-T on A-8-5 you had A-T on T-9-6, you should be much more\ninclined to bet for value and protection on the turn because there are numerous cards\nthat could come that could easily give your opponent the best hand. Always try to\nthink about how the hand will play out if you take each possible betting line. If the\nboard could easily run out terribly for you, you should probably bet for value and\nprotection. If the board will usually run out decently well for your hand and your\nopponent will play in an aggressive manner with a wide range if you check, you should\ncheck to induce a bluff.', metadata={'source': 'players/jonathan_little/little_pdfs/Strategies.pdf', 'page': 25}),
 Document(page_content='While it may seem like checking is the only way to induce a bluff, you can also bet into\nsome of your aggressive opponents and induce a bluff. For example, suppose a player\nwho plays too many hands in an aggressive manner raises to 2.5 big blinds out of his\n50 big blind stack from middle positon and you call from the big blind with 3\n-3\n.\nThe flop comes J\n-6\n-3\n. While going for a check-raise is a fine play, betting into your\nopponent is also a good option against this type of player. If you check-raise, or even\ncheck-call, your opponent will know that you at least have something. However,\nespecially if you have an aggressive dynamic with your opponent, if you bet into him\nfor around 3.5 big blinds, he may think that you are trying to push him off his hand,\nwhich he probably knows should not be too strong on this board. He may decide to\nrepresent a J or he may simply think you cannot withstand immense pressure,\nresulting in him either raising the flop or calling the flop and then taking an aggressive\naction on the turn.\nSo, you lead for 3.5 big blinds and your opponent raises to 9 big blinds. At this point,\nyou should go into call-down mode. You do not want to let your opponent think that\nyou have a premium hand by reraising. You also don’t want him to fold because most\nof his range is drawing nearly dead. Of course, he will outdraw you occasionally when\nhe improves to a straight, but that is a risk you must be willing to take if you want to\nmaximize your expectation from your premium holding.\nOn the turn, you should again check-call with the intention of check-calling the river,\ngiving your opponent the maximum number of opportunities to spew off his chips. If', metadata={'source': 'players/jonathan_little/little_pdfs/Strategies.pdf', 'page': 26}),
 Document(page_content='he checks behind on the turn, he either has nothing, which will not call a river bet, or a\nmarginal made hand. If you check the river, if he has J, he will probably bet for value\nand if he has worse than an J, he probably won’t call if you bet, assuming you have\nsome sort of strong hand that can beat middle pair. So, if the turn checks through, you\nshould check the river.\nInterestingly, if you check the river and your opponent bets, depending on the turn\nand river card, you may want to only check-call because you could be beat and most\nopponents will assume that you must have a premium hand to check-raise the river.\nThis means that your opponent will probably only call a check-raise on coordinated\nboards with overly premium hands, most of which you lose to. For example, if the\nboard runs out J\n-6\n-3\n-8\n-9\n, you should check-call. If it runs out J\n-6\n-3\n-T\n-A\n,\nyou should usually check-raise.\nAnother way you can induce an aggressive player to bluff is by making a tiny bet into\nyour opponent that looks like a classic blocking bet. A blocking bet is a small bet\nplaced with a marginal made hand, usually on the river, to induce your opponent into\ncalling with his strong hands while making it difficult for him to bluff. Using blocking\nbets in this manner is almost always a bad idea in today’s games because most players\nwill play well against them.\nHowever, if you know your opponent is an overly aggressive player who will attack any\nsign of weakness, turning the concept of a blocking bet on its head is an excellent idea.\nSuppose one of these players raises to 2.5 big blinds out of his 100 big blind stack from', metadata={'source': 'players/jonathan_little/little_pdfs/Strategies.pdf', 'page': 27}),
 Document(page_content='middle position, the Button calls and you call with A\n-3\n from the big blind.\nThe flop comes A\n-7\n-6\n. You check, the initial raiser bets 5 big blinds, the Button\nfolds and you call. The turn is the (A\n-7\n-6\n)-2\n. Both players check. The river is the\n(A\n-7\n-6\n-2\n)-J\n. This is an excellent spot to make a tiny bet of around 2.5 big blinds\ninto the 18 big blind pot because your aggressive opponent probably doesn’t have an\nA because he checked behind on the turn. This bet will result in your opponent calling\nwith any sort of made hand, which is an excellent result, and either folding or raising\nwith his absolute junk. If he folds, he will become suspicious that you bluffed him,\nperhaps allowing you to get unwarranted action on future hands. If he raises, you can\nhappily call because you know that in his eyes, you look as if you have a weak made\nhand and are trying to get to a cheap showdown.\nIt is important to size your river bet to induce your opponent into doing what you\nwant him to do. If you bet 7 big blinds on the river instead of 2.5, your opponent will\nalmost never raise as a bluff, which is what you are trying to induce. Instead, your\nopponent will call with all of his reasonably strong made hands and fold everything\nelse. A large bet leads to much worse results for you compared to the tiny bet. Always\ntry to quantify what your opponent will do when facing bets of all sizes then pick the\none that works out best for you.\nThe other main way to take advantage of this type of player is by bluffing them when\nthe board is good for your range and bad for their range. You have to realize that this\ntype of player plays a wide range of hands, meaning they could have anything. Even', metadata={'source': 'players/jonathan_little/little_pdfs/Strategies.pdf', 'page': 28}),
 Document(page_content='though they could conceivably connect with many more flops than a tight player,\naround 2/3 of the time this type of player will miss the flop. This should lead you to\nattack their continuation bets fairly often, especially when you should have a strong\nrange.\nFor example, suppose one of these players raises to 2.5 big blinds out of his 50 big\nblind stack from early position, the Cutoff calls and you call with A\n-J\n from the big\nblind. It is worth noting that it is usually wise to call when you are out of position with\nhands that play reasonably well after the flop. Most amateur players reraise with\ndecent high card hands like A-J and K-Q because they are usually best at the moment.\nEspecially when you are out of position, this is usually not a good enough reason to\njustify bloating the pot.\nThe flop comes 8\n-7\n-4\n. You check, the initial raiser bets 4 big blinds and the Cutoff\nfolds. This is an excellent spot to check-raise to around 11 big blinds with a wide range\nof premium made hands, draws and the occasional bluff. Anytime you have the\nbackdoor nut flush draw, which you have with the A\n, you should at least consider\nbluffing. Even if you didn’t have the A\n, you should bluff in this situation from time to\ntime because it is so easy for you to have a strong hand while at the same time, it is so\ndifficult for your opponent to have a strong hand. Even if he has A-A, he cannot be\nthrilled to pile money into the pot because he could be against a straight, set or\nstraight flush draw. Whenever you can put your opponent in a terrible spot with the\ntop of his range, especially if your opponent thinks you are relatively tight and', metadata={'source': 'players/jonathan_little/little_pdfs/Strategies.pdf', 'page': 29}),
 Document(page_content='straightforward, you should do it.\nIf your opponent happens to call your flop check-raise, you should usually continue\nbetting if the turn is a spade(\n) Q, J, T, 9, 8, 6 or 5. By betting you can easily represent\nthat you either had the nuts on the flop and are still happy with your hand or that you\nhave improved to a premium hand on the turn. You do not need to bet too large on\nthe turn because if you happened to have the nuts instead of a bluff, you would easily\nbe able to go all-in by the river by making a small turn bet. Notice if you had the nuts,\nyou would not want to let your opponent off the hook on the turn by betting too\nlarge. So, bet around 12 big blinds out of your 36.5 big blind stack into the 32 big blind\npot.\nIf your opponent decides to call your turn bet, you will have a tough spot on the river.\nYou should tend to bet again only if you think your opponent will fold most of his\nrange. If your opponent is a calling station, someone who rarely folds any sort of made\nhand, you should not have bluffed in this situation to begin with. Always remember to\npick your spots well and only run bluffs when there is a reasonably high likelihood of\nsuccess.', metadata={'source': 'players/jonathan_little/little_pdfs/Strategies.pdf', 'page': 30}),
 Document(page_content='Those\twho\tplay\ttoo\tfew\thands\n \nWhile players who play too few hands come in numerous varieties, you can generally\nbreak this category of players down into those who play too few hands too passively\nand those who play too few hands too aggressively.', metadata={'source': 'players/jonathan_little/little_pdfs/Strategies.pdf', 'page': 31}),
 Document(page_content='Those\twho\tplay\ttoo\tfew\thands\ttoo\npassively\n \nThis type of player rarely puts a chip in the pot, especially after the flop, without what\nthey perceive to be clearly the best hand. You will find that these players are deathly\nafraid of losing their entire stack. Some of them will even fold super-strong hands, such\nas A-K on K-8-6-2, if you apply enough pressure. That being said, some of these players\nwill never fold hands they think are strong. They assume that since they rarely enter\nthe pot, they have to win almost every hand they play. Be sure to pay attention to\nyour specific opponent and quantify exactly which mistakes he is making. Trying to\nbluff someone who is unbluffable is a devastating mistake.\nThese players usually do not defend their blinds well, especially if you raise and then\nmake a post-flop continuation bet. They refuse to continue after the flop without at\nleast a pair. If they check-call, they usually have top pair or worse. They typically make\nyour decisions easy by check-raising with hands that are better than top pair, allowing\nyou to easily fold when you are beat. If you are lucky enough to find one of these\nplayers who will check-call the flop with middle pair and worse but check-raise with\ntop pair and better, you can fire the turn every time your opponent check-calls the', metadata={'source': 'players/jonathan_little/little_pdfs/Strategies.pdf', 'page': 32}),
 Document(page_content='flop, allowing you to steal the pot whenever your opponent doesn’t improve to trips\nor two pair.\nMost of these players think that the goal of a poker tournament is to get in the money,\nlocking up a min-cash. This mindset is the exact opposite of what you should have.\nWhile getting in the money is nice, the real goal is to finish in the top three spots,\nwinning a large number of buy-ins. If you min-cash in a 120 person tournament 30% of\nthe time and lose all of the rest of them, you will lose money in the long run. However,\nif you win 4% of the time and lose the rest of them, you will win a ton of money. If you\nwant to succeed at poker, you must embrace the fact that you will experience large\nswings to your bankroll.\nThere are lots of ways to crush this type of opponent, mostly by taking advantage of\nthe fact that they will fold too often. You will find that most of these players are quick\nto fold when facing a pre-flop raise when they are in the blinds. If they happen to call\npre-flop, they will usually fold to a post-flop continuation bet.\nIf one of these players is in the big blind and the players between you and the big\nblind are not too wild, especially if you have a reasonably tight image, from middle or\nlate position, you should raise to roughly 2.5 big blinds with a wide range, hoping to\nsteal the blinds. For example, from middle position, hands such as A\n-4\n, K\n-9\n and 8\n-5\n should usually be folded if the players yet to act play reasonably well. However, if\nthey are mostly tight and passive, you should happily raise, expecting to steal the\nblinds most of the time. If one of your opponents decides to reraise, you should fold', metadata={'source': 'players/jonathan_little/little_pdfs/Strategies.pdf', 'page': 33}),
 Document(page_content='because your hand is certainly crushed by their range.\nFrom late position, your raising range should be even wider. Taken to the extreme, if\nyou are on the button and both players in the blinds are overly tight and passive, you\ncan raise with any two cards. In general though, from any position, you should not fret\nabout folding the absolute worst hands, such as 9-4, 7-3 and 5-2. It is good for your\nimage to show your opponents that you can fold from the button from time to time.\nPeople usually don’t mind if you steal a decent amount, but if you steal every single\ntime, they will start to become aware of your strategy.\nIf you raise with a junky hand and one of the tight, passive players calls , you should\nalmost always make a continuation bet of around 40% of the size of the pot, which will\nbe around 2.5 or 3 big blinds. This will give you an excellent price on your bluff while\nstill getting your opponent to fold almost every time he fails to improve on the flop. If\nyour opponent calls your flop bet, unless you have a strong hand, you should tend to\ngive up. Against the rare player who plays too few hands too passively but is a bit\nsticky after the flop, meaning he rarely folds to continuation bets, you should probably\nfire a second barrel on the turn, especially when scary cards arrive.\nIf you raise pre-flop and get multiple callers, you should usually play in a\nstraightforward manner, betting when you have something decent and getting out of\nthe way when you miss.\nSince most of these players really want to get in the money, you should look to exploit', metadata={'source': 'players/jonathan_little/little_pdfs/Strategies.pdf', 'page': 34}),
 Document(page_content='them late in the tournament whenever you are approaching a payout jump. Do not be\nafraid to reraise them with a decently wide range, especially when they make a raise\nfrom late position, where they could conceivably be stealing.\nFor example, suppose you are almost in the money and one of these players raises to\n3 big blinds out of his 40 big blind stack from the button. You are in the small blind\nwith K\n-4\n. This is an excellent spot to at least consider reraising to around 8.5 big\nblinds. If your opponent 4-bets to perhaps 17 big blinds or all-in, you can easily fold\nbecause you are certainly in awful shape. If he calls, you can bet 8.5 big blinds on the\nflop and usually steal the pot. Of course, if your opponent continues to the turn, you\nshould give up unless you have an overly strong holding because in order for your\nopponent to call your flop bet, he should have a strong hand that he is willing to put\nhis stack in with.\nThat being said, do not get too wild against this type of player. Especially when there is\na ton of money on the line, some of these players will only enter the pot with hands\nthat they do not plan on folding to any amount of aggression. These players may be so\ntight that they will not even consider stealing the blinds from late position. Instead,\nthey patiently wait for A-A, K-K, Q-Q, J-J, T-T, 9-9, A-K or A-Q and then try to get their\nstack in.\nYou crush players who play this tight by folding. This may sound counterintuitive, but\nevery time you do not give these players action when they have a premium hand, you\nsave a ton of money. Coupled with stealing their blinds relentlessly, they will slowly', metadata={'source': 'players/jonathan_little/little_pdfs/Strategies.pdf', 'page': 35}),
 Document(page_content='get ground down, losing roughly .6 big blinds per orbit.\nThat .6 big blinds per orbit number comes from the fact that these players will play\naround one in 12 hands that they are dealt. If you never give them action without an\nequally premium hand, they will win the blinds once every 12 on average while\nforfeiting their blinds once every nine hands.\nFor example, at 500/1,000-100, it costs 2,400 to play each orbit, which works out to, on\naverage, 267 chips per hand. If a tight player successfully steals 2,400 once every 12\nhands, he will steal 200 chips per steal attempt on average. This will result in him\nlosing 67 chips per hand, or 603 chips per orbit. Using this strategy, if he has a\nreasonable stack of 25,000 chips, he will lose 25% of his stack in only 93 hands. As the\nblinds continue to increase, his stack will diminish even faster.  \nThis is why most of these players are decently good at getting in the money before the\nblinds get too high but terrible at winning the tournament once the blinds get big,\nwhich in turn makes them terrible at winning money in poker tournaments. While it is\nnot too costly to only play premium hands when the blinds are small compared to\nyour stack, as the blinds increase, losing .6 big blinds per orbit is a disaster.\nThis is why you see lots of excellent players implementing a snug strategy early in the\ntournament but an almost maniacal strategy once the blinds get high. When the pre-\nflop pots become significant, you simply must fight for them, especially if your\nopponents will let you run them over. If you don’t, you are certain to lose money in', metadata={'source': 'players/jonathan_little/little_pdfs/Strategies.pdf', 'page': 36}),
 Document(page_content='the long run.\nOf course, the math is not quite that simple because these players will occasionally get\naction whenever their opponents play poorly by getting involved with vastly inferior\nhands. Notice they will effectively break even in situations where two players both\nhave premium hands because all players will get the same amount of premium hands\nin the long run. If you know a guy is only entering the pot with premium hands,\nespecially once the stacks get short, refuse to give him action unless you also have a\npremium hand. You don’t have to enter the pot simply because your hand is normally\nplayable against the average opponent.\nFor example, suppose a player who plays too few hands too passively raises to 2 big\nblinds out of his 28 big blind stack from second position. You have A-Q in middle\nposition. You should easily fold. While this may sound incredibly tight to some\nreaders, you must realize that A-Q is in marginal shape, at best, against this player’s\nlikely strong raising range. In fact, you should even consider folding decent pairs such\nas 9-9 in this situation.\nNot only do you have to worry about the initial raiser, but you also have to take into\naccount the players yet to act, who will each pick up a premium hand around 3% of the\ntime. Even though hands such as A-Q and 9-9 are normally quite playable, they could\neasily be crushed by this player’s early position raising range. Therefore, you don’t\nwant to reraise, and calling will lead to situations where you are frequently dominated\npost-flop. You should fold and wait for a better spot.', metadata={'source': 'players/jonathan_little/little_pdfs/Strategies.pdf', 'page': 37}),
 Document(page_content='If you fail to pay off the tight, passive players, you will slowly grind them down in the\nlong run. Do not impatiently donate your stack to them.', metadata={'source': 'players/jonathan_little/little_pdfs/Strategies.pdf', 'page': 38}),
 Document(page_content='Those\twho\tplay\ttoo\tfew\thands\ttoo\naggressively\n \nThis is the second most common player type, after those who play too many hands too\npassively, that you will encounter in small stakes poker tournaments. These players\nhave usually studied a few of the older poker books that say that “tight is right”. These\nolder poker books suggest waiting around for a strong hand before applying extreme\npressure, hoping to either win the pot with no contest (which is not actually a good\nresult; when you have best hand, you want to get value) or get all-in with what should\nbe the best hand (but often isn’t when a ton of money goes into the pot). Clearly these\nplayers have huge holes in their games that you can exploit.\nThese players tend to vastly overplay marginal made hands such as top pair and\noverpairs. When they make a hand they think is strong, they want to pile their stack\ninto the pot as fast as possible before the board gets too scary. It is not uncommon to\nsee these players raise to 3 big blinds out of their 100 big blind stack with a hand such\nas A-Q, get one caller from the blinds and flop Q-9-4. They then continuation bet 5 big\nblinds and face a check-raise to 13 big blinds. Instead of considering their opponent’s\ncheck-raising range, they hastily either reraise small to 30 big blinds with the intention', metadata={'source': 'players/jonathan_little/little_pdfs/Strategies.pdf', 'page': 39}),
 Document(page_content='of getting all-in on the turn or simply push all-in on the flop. They are usually shocked\nwhen their opponent shows them either a set or Q-9. Instead of taking time to realize\nthat they played their hand poorly, they curse the poker gods for their bad luck.\nBy blasting their stacks in whenever they have a strong hand, they give their\nopponents huge implied odds. They are simply not capable of folding “strong” hands\nthat are fairly difficult to make. Obviously if you are crushed by your opponent’s range,\nwhich should be quite strong if they recognize you are a tight, aggressive player, you\nshould fold all but your absolute best hands when a lot of money goes into the pot.\nYou can easily beat this type of player by playing against them primarily with overly\npremium hands, such as K-K and A-K and hands that have huge implied odds, such as\n3-3, A\n-3\n and 8\n-7\n. You want to play the premium hands because they have even a\ntight range crushed and you want to play the implied odds hands because you\nfrequently get paid off whenever you improve to a strong post-flop hand. Of course, if\nthe stacks are shallow, the implied odds hands lose a lot of value because you will not\nbe able to win too much, even when you hit.\nYou want to make a point to avoid hands that are easily dominated against this type\nof opponent. A\n-9\n and K\n-T\n are particularly bad because it is relatively easy to\nmake a strong, but dominated hand, such as with K-T on K-7-3. The last thing you want\nto do is play hands that frequently either lose large pots or win small ones. When\nfacing a raise from a tight, aggressive player, unless your hand is almost certainly\nahead or has a ton of post-flop potential, simply fold and wait for a better spot.', metadata={'source': 'players/jonathan_little/little_pdfs/Strategies.pdf', 'page': 40}),
 Document(page_content='If you happen to find yourself in a situation where you have a decently strong, but not\namazing, post-flop hand, make a point to not lose your entire stack when your tight,\naggressive opponent clearly wants to put a lot of chips in the pot. For example,\nsuppose a player who plays too many hands too aggressively raises to 1,000 at\n200/400-50 from middle positon out of his 20,000 stack. You decide to call on the\nbutton with K\n-Q\n. The blinds fold. It is worth noting that you should almost never\nreraise with this hand before the flop against this type of player.\nThe flop comes (K\n-7\n-2\n). Your opponent bets 1,500 and you call. Folding would be\ntoo tight as you could easily be against numerous worse hands such as T-T and A-Q.\nThe turn is the (K\n-7\n-2\n)-9\n. Your opponent bets 2,600. At this point, you should be\nconcerned that you could have the worst hand. While you could make a case for\nfolding against the tightest players who only continue betting on the turn with top\npair, top kicker and better made hands, you should usually call one more time to see\nwhat develops on the river.\nIt is mandatory that you formulate a plan for the river before you call on the turn. If\nyour opponent bets a third time, you should probably fold, giving him credit for K-J or\nbetter. Of course, you beat K-J, but you lose to everything else. Sometimes your\nopponent will accidently turn a worse made hand into a bluff. Don’t let that bother\nyou. Most of the time when you will be crushed.\nIf your opponent checks on the river, you should probably check behind unless you are', metadata={'source': 'players/jonathan_little/little_pdfs/Strategies.pdf', 'page': 41}),
 Document(page_content='confident your opponent would bet with A-K and better, meaning his checking range\nconsist entirely of hands that you beat.\nSo, the river is the (K\n-7\n-2\n-9\n)-4\n. Your opponent bets 5,500. Sticking with the plan,\nyou should fold. While you may have the best hand some small percentage of the\ntime, you are almost certainly beat. Remember, a penny saved is a penny earned!\nBe aware that you should almost never make this fold versus a loose player who is\nprone to betting with a much wider range, either for value or as a bluff. You should\nalso not fold versus players who vastly overvalue strong pre-flop hands that failed to\nimprove after the flop, such as J-J or A-Q on the (K\n-7\n-2\n-9\n)-4\n board. Always take\nyour opponent’s tendencies into consideration.\nSince these players tend to be a bit too tight before the flop, you can slowly grind\nthem down by stealing their blinds whenever you find an opportunity. Do not be\nafraid to attack their blinds even from early or middle position, especially if the players\nbetween you and the blinds are relatively tight.\nSuppose everyone folds to you in the cutoff and you look down at 8\n-4\n. The effective\nstack size is 40 big blinds. The Button, Small Blind and Big Blind are all players who\nplay too few hands. You should strongly consider raising to around 2.3 big blinds. If\nyou get reraised, you should fold. If one player calls, you should almost always make a\n2.5 big blind continuation bet on the flop. If multiple players call, you should usually\nplay in a straightforward manner after the flop. Remember, your goal is to steal the', metadata={'source': 'players/jonathan_little/little_pdfs/Strategies.pdf', 'page': 42}),
 Document(page_content='blinds. When you face too much resistance, don’t be afraid to get out of the way. Of\ncourse, if the Button, Small Blind and Big Blind don’t like to fold before the flop, you\nshould easily fold your awful 8-4.\nSimilarly to how you should combat tight, passive opponents and loose, passive\nopponents, when a tight, aggressive player decides to reraise you before the flop or\napply significant pressure after the flop, unless you are getting huge implied odds with\na hand that has a decent chance to improve, you should fold. Remember, you win a\nhuge amount of equity by staying out of trouble when your opponent’s range has you\ncrushed.\nFor example, you raise from the hijack seat to 2.3 big blinds out of your 35 big blind\nstack with A\n-J\n. The Button, a tight player who plays his strong hands too\naggressively, decides to reraise to 7 big blinds. This is situation where you should make\nan easy fold. You are usually dominated and when you aren’t, you have to play a tricky\nhand out of position that will fail to connect with the flop 2/3 of the time. While going\nall-in would be an option against a loose, aggressive player, against a tight player, it is\nnot a good idea because your opponent will play perfectly, calling with his hands that\nbeat you and folding those that don’t.\nWhile the reraiser in this example could easily exploit you by reraising with a much\nwider range, you can rest assured that most of these players will rarely get out of line.\nThey have been taught to reraise with their strong hands and fold everything else.\nThose are their rules and they are sticking to them. Of course, if you notice that your', metadata={'source': 'players/jonathan_little/little_pdfs/Strategies.pdf', 'page': 43}),
 Document(page_content='opponent is constantly reraising you despite your assumption that he should be\nplaying a snug range, you may need to reassess your read and start fighting back.', metadata={'source': 'players/jonathan_little/little_pdfs/Strategies.pdf', 'page': 44}),
 Document(page_content='Those\twho\tplay\troughly\tthe\tcorrect\namount\tof\thands\tin\tan\tintelligent\nmanner\n \nWhile these players tend to quickly move up from the small stakes games to larger\nbuy-in games where they can win more money, all good players must start somewhere.\nThese players tend to be on the tighter side while being capable of running well-timed\npost-flop bluffs and getting away from hands that are reasonably strong, but obviously\ncrushed. One sign of a strong player is that they usually win a lot of small pots,\nespecially on the turn and the river without a showdown, while at the same time,\nrarely playing a large pot without a premium holding.\nOne of the main ways to beat this type of player is by applying significant pressure in\nintelligent spots where your range should be stronger than your opponent’s. For\nexample, suppose one of these players raises from early position and you call on the\nbutton. If the flop comes 8\n-7\n-6\n and your opponent bets, this is an excellent spot\nto raise with an overly wide range because the board should be much better for your\nrange than your opponent’s.', metadata={'source': 'players/jonathan_little/little_pdfs/Strategies.pdf', 'page': 45}),
 Document(page_content='Especially in the small stakes games, many of these players are well versed in the idea\nof betting for value with a reasonably wide value range with the intention of folding if\nraised. Use their dependence on this play against them. Suppose one of these players\nraises from middle position and you call in the big blind with 9\n-7\n. The flop comes A\n-9\n-6\n. You check, your opponent bets and you call. The turn is the (A\n-9\n-6\n)-T\n .\nYou check and your opponent bets again. Seeing how you almost certainly have the\nworst hand at the moment, calling is not a good idea. However, you could check-raise\nas a semi-bluff, assuming the stacks are deep enough that you have some fold equity.\nIf you know that your opponent would value bet any A on the turn with the intention\nof folding if he gets raised, you should check-raise with a wide range of hands that are\nnot quite good enough to continue check-calling with.\nAnother way to exploit these players is by folding when it is clear they want to put a\nlot of money in the pot. Assuming you know that your specific opponent rarely\nattempts somewhat wild flop and turn check-raises, if he check-raises you, do not be\nafraid to make a big fold. Of course, if your opponent is somewhat wild after the flop,\nyou should be a bit more prone to see a showdown.\nWhile trying to exploit every player you encounter is a good idea, it is usually a good\nidea to avoid strong players and focus your attention on crushing the weak players,\nwho are easily exploitable. Remember, you win money at poker because your\nopponents make mistakes. If your opponents do not make many mistakes, you will not\nwin much of their money.', metadata={'source': 'players/jonathan_little/little_pdfs/Strategies.pdf', 'page': 46}),
 Document(page_content='Assuming you are one of these strong players, which you either currently are or are\nworking to become, you must be keenly aware of how your opponents view you.\nRemember, each specific opponent will have his own perception about you. Perhaps\nyou won a big pot with no showdown against a player who may now think you are\ncapable of bluffing. Even though you may have won the pot with a legitimately strong\nhand, he will be suspicious. Maybe another guy at the same table lost a sizable pot to\nyou when you called his bluff with middle pair. He may think you are a calling station.\nPerhaps you have folded your big blind to the same player’s pre-flop raise a few orbits\nin a row because you had trashy cards. He may think you are overly tight in the blinds.\nIt is important to realize that the way your opponents perceive you is based on what\nthey see, not what you see. You have to look at the world from your opponent’s point\nof view. You will find that this is initially a difficult thing to do, but if you constantly\npractice, you will get better at it over time.\nIf your opponent expects you to be tight, you should bluff more often. If you have\nplayed very few hands recently, feel free to get well out of line and play a marginal\nhand as if it is the nuts. Suppose you have been somewhat tight recently and decide to\nraise from middle position with A-4 to 2 big blinds out of your 50 big blind stack. A\nloose, aggressive player who loves to reraise reraises you to 5 big blinds from the\nbutton. This is an excellent spot to reraise to around 11.5 big blinds. It will put the\nButton in a difficult spot with most of his non-premium range because it looks as if you\nare willing to get your entire stack in. Of course, if the Button decides to put his stack\nin despite your aggression, you should get out of the way. You must accept that', metadata={'source': 'players/jonathan_little/little_pdfs/Strategies.pdf', 'page': 47}),
 Document(page_content='sometimes your bluffs will fail, even if you have been playing a tight strategy.\nAnother time you can get well out of line is when, in the past against a specific player,\nyou have had premium holdings most of the time. If a specific player thinks that you\nonly play strong hands, unless he is a calling station, he will make big folds to you on\nthe turn and river when you take a line that he only thinks you would take with a\nstrong hand. If your opponent thinks you are crazy, you should tend to value bet with\na much wider range than normal, especially if your opponent will refuse to fold A high\nor better, regardless of the board. When you have a reasonable idea of how you think\nyour opponents expects you to play, it is wise to play your premium hands as your\nopponent thinks you would play your bluffs and your bluffs as he thinks you would\nplay your premium hands.', metadata={'source': 'players/jonathan_little/little_pdfs/Strategies.pdf', 'page': 48}),
 Document(page_content='Pay\tattention!\n \nI cannot make it clearer that you simply must pay attention to what your opponents\nare doing if you want to succeed at poker. You should actively quantify the mistakes\nyour opponents are making and what you can do to exploit those mistakes. If you find\nyourself thinking “My opponent is bad” then you aren’t quantifying your opponent’s\nweaknesses well. Instead, you should think something along the lines of “My opponent\ncalls with a wide range pre-flop and on the flop and then plays much too tightly on the\nturn. This means I should bet almost every time on the turn when my opponent calls\nmy pre-flop raise and my flop continuation bet.” Or perhaps “My opponent in the big\nblind folds his big blind to 2.2 big blind raises almost every time but frequently calls\nwhen I raise to 2 big blinds. I should raise to 2.2 big blinds because that will result in\nme stealing the blinds much more often.” By quantifying what you can do to succeed\nagainst each player, you will be better able to develop a game plan that will allow you\nto exploit your opponents as much as possible.\nIt is important to realize that as you improve, your opponents will have fewer and\nfewer flaws in their game. If you do not work hard at developing your observation skills\nin the small stakes games, you will not be adequately prepared when you move up.\nI realize that giving your full attention to poker while at the table is not easy. I suggest', metadata={'source': 'players/jonathan_little/little_pdfs/Strategies.pdf', 'page': 49}),
 Document(page_content='that you make a game out of trying to put each player on a range of hands and seeing\nif you are right when the cards sporadically get turned face-up. This will keep you\nfocused on the game and improve your hand-reading abilities at the same time.\nAnother tip is to do something at the start of every hand that signifies to you that you\nneed to focus. Some players snap a rubber band around their wrists and others move\na chip from the top of one stack to the top of another stack. Whatever you do, do not\nbe lulled into a trance by the dealer’s shuffling or the constant sound of chips banging\ntogether.\nI also suggest that you don’t shuffle your poker chips, whether or not you are involved\nin a pot. While this action may seem innocuous enough, you will find that it is purely a\ndistraction. If you are distracted, you will not focus as well as possible.\nIf you find yourself not paying attention while you are playing, gently scold yourself\nand resolve to make the most of your time at the poker table. Do not be too hard on\nyourself though. It is incredibly easy to lose focus. If you improve a little bit each time\nyou play, given time, you will be excellent.', metadata={'source': 'players/jonathan_little/little_pdfs/Strategies.pdf', 'page': 50}),
 Document(page_content='Specific\ttendencies\tyou\twill\tencounter\nin\tsmall\tstakes\ttournaments\n \nWhile all players are different, you will likely discover that there are a few key leaks\nthat small stakes players have in addition to the ones that have been previously\ndiscussed which keep them from succeeding. In this section, I will outline some of\nthese devastating traits that your opponents will display on a regular basis.\nRemember, you will only discover these traits if you are actively paying attention. If\nyou are constantly playing on your phone or watching TV, you will miss out on this\nequity.\nSuppose you see that a player raises with a wide range of hands before the flop but\nfolds when he is reraised unless he has a premium hand. Against this type of player,\nyou should frequently reraise, forcing him to fold most of his range.\nFor example, if someone with this tendency raises from middle position and you are in\nlate position, do not be afraid to reraise to around three times your opponent’s initial\nraise. This will apply a lot of pressure and frequently result in you winning the pot\nwithout seeing a flop. If your opponent calls your reraise, you should probably make a\npost-flop continuation bet that is roughly the size of your pre-flop reraise on most', metadata={'source': 'players/jonathan_little/little_pdfs/Strategies.pdf', 'page': 51}),
 Document(page_content='boards. If your opponent is still in the pot at that point, you should assume he has a\ndecently strong hand. You should get out of the way unless you also have a strong\nhand. As long as you use this play sporadically, it will remain hugely profitable.\nSuppose you see that a player raises with a reasonable range before the flop and then\ncontinuation bets on the flop 100% of the time. When he gets raised or check-raised,\nhe only continues in the pot if he has top pair or better. This is an excellent player to\nraise or check-raise on the flop with a wide range, especially on boards that should not\nbe good for the pre-flop raiser’s range.\nFor example, suppose someone with this tendency raises from middle position and\nyou call on the button. Pretty much no matter what the flop comes, you should at\nleast consider raising if your opponent continuation bets. You could also call your\nopponent’s continuation bet then bet the turn if he checks to you or raise his turn bet\nif he fires again. Since your opponent’s range is wide, if he doesn’t defend well against\nraises, he will frequently concede the pot to you.\nSuppose you know your opponent raises to 5 big blinds before the flop with exactly J-J\nand T-T. You know that this player raises to 3 big blinds with every other hand in his\nraising range. You also know that he will never fold J-J and T-T pre-flop to any amount\nof aggression, as long as you do not go all-in. If you reraise small, he will usually reraise\nall-in, not wanting to get outdrawn by what he thinks is your “obvious” A-K.\nSince your opponent’s hand is effectively face up when he raises to 5 big blinds, you', metadata={'source': 'players/jonathan_little/little_pdfs/Strategies.pdf', 'page': 52}),
 Document(page_content='should fold all of your trash that is drawing thin, call with your hands that have huge\nimplied odds as well as with your over cards and reraise with premium pairs (J-J and\nbetter).\nIf you know more about this opponent’s post-flop tendencies, you should consider\ncalling with a wide range of hands with the intention of stealing the pot when an over\ncard comes if you know your opponent will give you credit for having him beat. If your\nopponent will never fold regardless of the board because he views J-J and T-T as super-\npremium hands, you should only play hands that have your opponent’s narrow range\ncrushed or hands that have the proper equity or implied odds to continue.\nThese examples should get you started thinking about all of the possible ways to\nexploit your opponent’s tendencies once you become aware of them. If you make a\npoint to figure out when and where your opponents are making errors, if you are\nwilling to get out of your comfort zone, you will succeed in the long run.', metadata={'source': 'players/jonathan_little/little_pdfs/Strategies.pdf', 'page': 53}),
 Document(page_content='Conclusion\n \nAfter reading this book, you should be well-equipped to tackle the small stakes\ntournaments. As long as you remain mindful while at the table and actively quantify\nyour opponents’ tendencies, you will be on the road to beating the small stakes and\nmoving up to the middle stakes. I have a wealth of resources that will help you\ncontinue your journey. If you ever have any questions, please feel free to email me at\nsupport@jonathanlittlesecrets.com. Also,', metadata={'source': 'players/jonathan_little/little_pdfs/Strategies.pdf', 'page': 54}),
 Document(page_content='each month I, and a few of the other coaches, host a monthly webinar where you can\nask us any poker questions you have.\nAlso check out my books:\nSecrets of Professional Tournament Poker, Volumes 1-3\nThe Main Event with Jonathan Little\nJonathan Little on Live No-Limit Cash Games\nPositive Poker\nIt is important to remember that one of the best things you can do to improve your\ntournament play is to learn how to increase your levels of aggression. However, it must\nbe done intelligently for it to be effective. The key to using aggression effectively is\nknowing when to apply pressure and when to get out of the way.\nTo get a free 11-minute video and a 24-page PDF from me with tips on how to increase\nyour aggression, visit:\nFloatTheTurn.com/increasingaggression\nIf you enjoyed this book, please tell your friends about it. 13
[Document(page_content='Instructions \nThese preflop charts are designed to give you a fundamentally sound starting point for your preflop \ndecisions. While these charts will work well in most situations, you should adjust them to take your \nspecific situation into account. \n \nThere are three sets of charts. The Raise First In (RFI) charts show which hands to play when \neveryone folds to you. The Facing RFI charts show how to play when someone raises before you. \nThe RFI vs. 3-bet charts show how to play when you RFI and then someone yet to act 3-bets. \n \nThe charts assume 100 big blind effective stacks with an ante in play. They apply to roughly 50 big \nblind stacks and larger. \n \nMake the play listed from in position using a 2.5 big blind initial raise size, a 3-bet size that is 3 times \nthe opponent’s raise, and a 4-bet size that is 2.5 times the opponent’s 3-bet. From out of position, \nuse a 3.5 big blind initial raise size, a 3-bet size that is 3.5 times the opponent’s raise, and a 4-bet \nsize that is 2.75 times the opponent’s 3-bet. \n \nThese charts are an excellent default, but playing a default strategy in all situations will result in you \nbeing a roughly break-even poker player. Check out the PokerCoaching.com quizzes and challenges \nfor an in-depth look at when to deviate from the charts. Adjust to take advantage of whatever your \nopponents do incorrectly and the money will flow your way.', metadata={'source': 'players/jonathan_little/little_pdfs/full-preflop-charts.pdf', 'page': 1}),
